content.title: Cerebral Hyperperfusion Syndrome
content.description: A potentially fatal complication following carotid revascularization characterized by unilateral headache, seizures, and intracerebral hemorrhage due to loss of cerebrovascular autoregulation.
content.definition: Cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome (CHS) occurs when cerebral blood flow increases excessively following carotid endarterectomy or stenting due to impaired autoregulation in a chronically hypoperfused brain. Without treatment, it can progress to fatal intracerebral hemorrhage.

pathophysiology: Autoregulation impaired in chronically ischemic brain

clinical_pearls: Unilateral headache after CEA = hyperperfusion until proven otherwise
BP control is cornerstone of prevention and treatment
High-grade stenosis + contralateral occlusion = highest risk
Occurs 1-14 days post-procedure, peak at day 5-7
